Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Their teacher invited them to summarize key teachings for a temple session tomorrow.
Story: I sit on the edge of my bed, my phone buzzing with a message from my boyfriend: “Can’t wait for our weekend together.” It’s the last one before he leaves for months, and I know how much this time means to him—and to us. I want to be present, to laugh and hold his hand, to make memories that will last until he returns. But my heart is pulled in another direction. My Buddhist teacher just called, asking if I could prepare a summary of key teachings for tomorrow’s temple session. It’s an honor, and I know how important it is to support the sangha and deepen my own practice. I feel the weight of both expectations pressing on me. My boyfriend’s hopeful anticipation, the gentle but firm request from my teacher, and my own longing to be both a loving partner and a devoted practitioner. My mind races, torn between love and duty, between the warmth of shared moments and the quiet call of the Dharma.
